title: 105_hr2531
content: The Act may be cited as the "Radio Free Asia Act of 1997". The Congress finds that the Government of the People's Republic of China controls information flow, prioritizes political power over economic development, and censors computer networks. Premier Li Peng's order in 1997 requires organizations involved in international computer networking to obtain a license. The Government of the People's Republic of China controls information flow and censors computer networks. Organizations involved in international computer networking must now apply for a license, increasing government control over internet access. Radio Free Asia and Voice of America provide uncensored information to the Chinese people, broadcasting in Mandarin, Cantonese, and Tibetan languages. Radio Free Asia and Voice of America offer 24-hour broadcasting in Mandarin, Cantonese, and Tibetan, with plans to expand to other dialects in China. They aim to establish continuous Mandarin broadcasting by staggering their hours. Simultaneous broadcasting on Voice of America radio and Worldnet television in Mandarin is also crucial. Authorization of appropriations for increased funding for Radio Free Asia and Voice of America broadcasting to China. Authorization of appropriations for Radio Free Asia includes $30,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $22,000,000 for fiscal year 1999. Funds are allocated for one-time capital costs, advanced editing equipment, and additional personnel for Cantonese language broadcasting. Authorization of appropriations for International Broadcasting Activities to China includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $7,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, specifically for enhanced Voice of America broadcasting. Additionally, authorization of appropriations for Radio Construction includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $3,000,000 for fiscal year 1999. The authorization of appropriations for International Broadcasting Activities to China includes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 and $3,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, with $3,000,000 specifically for construction to enhance broadcasting. Additionally, $3,000,000 is authorized for transmitter augmentation at Tinian, Marshall Islands. The Director of the United States Information Agency and the Board of Broadcasting Governors aim to maintain funding levels for nations lacking freedom of expression. The President, in consultation with the Board of Broadcasting Governors, must report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment on a plan for continuous broadcasting of Radio Free Asia and Voice of America to China in various dialects and languages.
